flares.note: There may be a sympathetic flare from Active Region 14324 as well.

cmes.note: Very faint CME seen to the SE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1 and either to the ENE or (later) faintly to the SE in STEREO A COR2. Best seen in running difference imagery. The CME later overlaps with multiple eastern CME fronts, so analysis is not straightforward. One potential source could be a minor eruption in the newly numbered AR 14331 (S25E61) seen starting at 2025-12-30T06:00Z in SDO AIA/GOES SUVI 304, with ejecta directed southwardly, however the fit with three coronagraphs (SOHO LASCO C2/C3, STEREO A COR2 and GOES CCOR-1) strongly indicates a far-sided source. In addition to the brigher, dimpled bulk, there is a much fainter and wider shock, mostly seen to the S.

cmeAnalyses.note: Approximate analysis based on the fit of the faint dimpled front with three coronagraphs (SOHO LASCO C2/C3, STEREO A COR2 and GOES CCOR-1). No coronal signatures of a far-sided source seen in EUV imagery.

cmes.note: Faint CME seen to the NE in all three coronagraphs (SOHO LASCO C2/C3, STEREO A COR2 and GOES CCOR-1), with the faint front quickly becoming fuzzy/partially dissipating. The CME is somewhat overlapping with the more southern CME: 2025-12-30T07:00Z. A possible source is a narrow prominence/ejecta rotating northwardly seen starting at 2025-12-30T06:49Z in GOES SUVI 304 (and SDO AIA 304) on/behind the E limb (lat -15), however the fit between coronagraphs shows a much lower longitude, indicating AR 14324 (N25W33) as a possible source. There is a C3.5-class flare in this Active Region at the time.

cmeAnalyses.note: Analysis based on the fit with three coronagraphs (SOHO LASCO C2/C3, STEREO A COR2 and GOES CCOR-1) and including the northern portion of this fuzzy, dimpled front. Takes into account later timeframes of coronagraphs. Possible source is the C class flare from Active Region 14324.
Very preliminary analysis based on the fit with three coronagraphs (SOHO LASCO C2/C3, STEREO A COR2 and GOES CCOR-1).

cmes.note: A CME to the ESE, with the front clearest in STEREO A COR2 coronagraph and super faint in SOHO and GOES CCOR-1. No clear source has been found it could potentially be an impulsive C5.0 flare from Active Region 14325 (S09E27) peaking at 2025-12-30T06:45Z. There is one bright post-eruptive arcade after the flare as well, but no other coronal signatures.

cmeAnalyses.note: A very speculative analysis based on the fit of fronts in two coronagraphs (relatively clear front in STEREO A COR2 and a super faint partial halo front in SOHO LASCO C2 coronagraph). Not confirmed by a clear source, but there is an impulsive flare from Active Region 14325 at the time that fits the bill.

cmes.note: Faint, less than 10 degree half-width CME observed to the NNW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2. The source may be field line movement and filament activity on the farside, viewed only in low-cadence STEREO A EUVI 195 and EUVI 304 imagery starting around 2025-12-30T09:35Z on the west limb as viewed from STEREO A, putting this source around W140.

cmeAnalyses.note: Triangulation between SOHO LASCO C2, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2. CME half-width less than 10 degrees.

cmes.note: CME observed to the SE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1, not observed in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap beginning at 2025-12-30T16:53Z. The source is associated with a C4.1 class flare from AR 14330 (S17E42) which peaked at 2025-12-30T18:03Z observed in SDO AIA 131. Eruption also observed as brightening on disk and field line movement in SDO AIA 171/193/304.

cmeAnalyses.note: Single spacecraft 3D analysis with SOHO LASCO C2/C3 as STEREO A COR2 imagery not available for this CME, using the flare source of S17E42 as the longitude. As such, the longitude could easily vary E30-E50 if deflection occurred.

Single spacecraft 3D analysis with SOHO LASCO C2 as STEREO A COR2 imagery not available for this CME, using the flare source of S17E42 as the base longitude and adjusting for the shock width and shape, ending up around longitude E22.

cmes.note: CME visible to the NW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2. The potential source may be an eruption from Active Region 14322, which rotated off of the Earth-facing disk on 2025-12-28, as seen in STEREO A EUV 195 imagery around N15W130 as brightening and moving field lines starting around 2025-12-31T03:55Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3, STEREO A COR2, and GOES CCOR-1 in SWPC_CAT as well as the potential source location.

cmes.note: Partial halo CME visible to the NE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, STEREO A COR2, and GOES CCOR-1. It is associated with an M7.1 flare from AR 14324 (N24E20) peaking at 2025-12-31T13:51Z. Eruption with EUV wave, dimming, opening field lines, and post eruptive arcades are best seen in SDO AIA 193 imagery. The eruption is also visible near the east limb as seen from STEREO A EUV imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3, STEREO A COR2, and GOES CCOR-1 imagery in SWPC_CAT as well as the source location.
SHOCK measurement based best fit of SHOCK feature using running difference imagery from SOHO LASCO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2 as well as visible source location.

cmes.note: CME visible to the N in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1 and the NE in STEREO A COR2. The source may be a small eruption seen off the northern limb in GOES SUVI 304 starting at 2025-12-31T13:55Z, possibly originating from a small eruption in the far north near disk center.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2 in SWPC_CAT.

cmes.note: Faint CME first seen to the N in SOHO LASCO C2 starting around 2025-12-31T23:36Z. CME is also seen to the N in SOHO LASCO C3 and GOES CCOR-1 but is not visible in STEREO A COR2. This feature is much easier to see in running difference imagery. There is no visible source for this CME, so it is most likely either far-sided or outflow following CME: 2025-12-31T14:00Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement chosen due to lack of source candidate and lack of available coronagraph triangulation.

cmes.note: Narrow CME first seen to the E in STEREO A COR2 starting at 2026-01-01T03:53Z. This CME is only seen in STEREO A COR2 for four frames. The later propagation of this CME is missed due to a data gap in STEREO A COR2 imagery starting after 2026-01-01T03:48Z There are a couple of potential sources for this CME. The first is an eruption and some associated dimming from AR 14324 best seen in SDO AIA 193 starting around 2026-01-01T01:39Z. The second is associated with a C9.6 class flare from AR 14325 (S10E03) that peaked at 2026-01-01T02:25Z. The flare and associated eruption are best seen in SDO AIA 131. Based on the latitude of the CME, the second source candidate is more likely.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement chosen because this CME is only seen in STEREO A COR2.

cmes.note: CME first seen to the SE in SOHO LASCO C2 starting around 2026-01-01T06:24Z. This CME is also seen to the SE in SOHO LASCO C3 and GOES CCOR-1 but is covered by a data gap in STEREO A COR2. The source of this CME is a large filament eruption over the SE quadrant of the Earth-facing disk. The eruption is best seen in SDO AIA 304, and the filament can be seen rising as early as 2026-01-01T04:52Z. There is some brightening on the SE limb in running difference imagery as early as 2026-01-01-T05:36Z (likely associated with brightening from the rising filament itself), but the structure of the CME is not visible in white light imagery until 2026-01-01T06:24Z. There appears to be some deflection slightly to the south later into the propagation of the CME.

cmeAnalyses.note: Best-fit measurement based on running difference imagery from SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1 and on the visible location of the filament. There is also a wider, more northern portion that is not visible by the time the CME makes it into SOHO LASCO C3. Because the extra feature is not visible later in SOHO LASCO C3, the bright bulk has been prioritized for the measurement. The extra, wider feature is more prominent in GOES CCOR-1, but it is still not as bright as the main bulk. The approximate longitude of the filament footpoints is around E60 to E80. Since a triangulated measurement cannot be made as there is no STEREO A COR2 imagery for this event, a starting point of E60 was used for this measurement. Because of this, there will inherently be a greater than normal degree of uncertainty associated with this measurement.

cmes.note: CME first seen to the SE in SOHO LASCO C2 starting around 2026-01-01T13:36Z. The CME is also seen in SOHO LASCO C3 and GOES CCOR-1, but is not visible in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap starting after 2026-01-01T04:38Z. There is no good source candidate for this feature visible on the Earth-facing disk. This is likely just outflow following CME: 2026-01-01T06:24Z. There is some southward deflection later into the propagation past the FOV of SOHO LASCO C2.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement chosen due to lack of distinct source candidate and lack of available coronagraph triangulation.

cmes.note: CME first seen to the NNE by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2026-01-01T19:36Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and GOES CCOR-1 in later frames. This CME is currently not visible in STEREO A COR2 imagery due to a data gap which began at 2026-01-01T04:38Z. The source of this event is a C6.2 flare from AR 14324 (N24E01) seen in SDO AIA 131 peaking at 2026-01-01T17:59Z. A wide region of dimming and field line opening is also visible in SDO AIA 171, 193, 211 and GOES SUVI 284, followed by post eruptive arcades seen in SDO AIA 131 and 193.

cmeAnalyses.note: BULK measurement based on approximate source location and best fit in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1.
SHOCK measurement based on approximate source location and best fit in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1.

cmes.note: Faint loop CME first seen to the NW by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2026-01-01T23:12Z as well as by GOES CCOR-1 and STEREO A COR2 (after the data gap) in later frames. The source of this event is faint field line movement seen along the NW limb in SDO AIA 171 beginning at approx. 2026-01-01T22:36Z. The source could be Active Region 14317, which is in the process of rotation off the visible disk.

cmeAnalyses.note: Approximate analysis based on the fit with all three coronagraphs (SOHO LASCO C2/C3, STEREO A COR2 and GOES CCOR-1). The source is behind the NW limb in SDO and this event is covered by an unusually long data gap in STEREO A imagery.

cmes.note: Faint CME seen to the NW in SOHO LASCO C2 and CCOR-1. It is partially obscured by pylon in C3. The CME has a somewhat brighter narrow bulk and a very faint very wide (partial halo-like) shock. No clear source was found in EUV imagery but there is some minor movement of field lines well beyond the limb as seen in the W in GOES SUVI 284 after 2026-01-02T16:17Z. Some ejecta can also be seen from beyond the W limb in STA EUVI 304 around 2026-01-02T16:45Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Very approximate analysis of the faint wide shock of this CME with one-coronagraph method (SOHO LASCO and GOES CCOR-1 coronagraphs), based on the fit of the partial halo front with coronagraphs. The source is far-sided and the exact longitude is not known.

Preliminary BULK analysis, as a plane-of-sky with SOHO LASCO C2 and GOES CCOR-1 only due to the data gap in STEREO A COR2 and STEREO A EUVI starting around 2026-01-02T16:53Z imagery to see and triangulate the far-sided source.

cmes.note: Faint CME observed to the NW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1, not in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap beginning at 2026-01-02T16:53Z. The source is likely faintly observed on the NE disk as a slow filament eruption/surface brightening from two nearby areas, which likely created this CME and the following similar CME: 2026-01-02T21:12Z, with difficulty distinguishing the sources due to their proximity and slow nature. The first area observed as surface brightening in SDO AIA 304 is centered around N40E22 and starts erupting around 2026-01-02T17:30Z. The second area observed as a filament, which spanned approximately N50E20 to N45E10, slowly peeling off the disk in SDO AIA 304 starting as early as 2026-01-02T17:52Z. In SDO AIA 171 and GOES SUVI 284, both of these eruptions are observed deflecting field lines further to the NW from these areas, with some dimming in SDO AIA 193.

cmeAnalyses.note: SOHO LASCO C2 only plane-of-sky as no STEREO A COR2 imagery is available to triangulate this CME, which is observed deflected NW away from its source on the NE earth-facing disk.

cmes.note: Faint CME observed to the NW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1, not in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap beginning at 2026-01-02T16:53Z. The source is likely faintly observed on the NE disk as a slow filament eruption/surface brightening from two nearby areas, which likely created this CME and the preceeding similar CME: 2026-01-02T19:00Z, with difficulty distinguishing the sources due to their proximity and slow nature. The first area observed as surface brightening in SDO AIA 304 is centered around N40E22 and starts erupting around 2026-01-02T17:30Z. The second area observed as a filament, which spanned approximately N50E20 to N45E10, slowly peeling off the disk in SDO AIA 304 starting as early as 2026-01-02T17:52Z. In SDO AIA 171 and GOES SUVI 284, both of these eruptions are observed deflecting field lines further to the NW from these areas, with some dimming in SDO AIA 193.

cmeAnalyses.note: SOHO LASCO C2 only plane-of-sky as no STEREO A COR2 imagery is available to triangulate this CME, which is observed deflected NW away from its source on the NE earth-facing disk.

cmes.note: This CME is visible to the southeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is likely related to an eruption from Active Region 14334 (S18E70) starting around 2026-01-03T07:20Z seen in SDO AIA 131/171/193/304 and GOES SUVI 131/171/195/284/304 imagery. An opening of field lines can be observed over the southeast limb in GOES SUVI 284 imagery at this time.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

cmes.note: This CME is visible to the south/southeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source may be related to a filament eruption hovering near S30W65 which begins to lift off around 2026-01-03T08:00Z as seen in SDO AIA 171/193/304 and GOES SUVI 171/195/284/304 imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

cmes.note: Jet CME seen to the southeast in SOHO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2A associated with a point source eruption near the vicinity of AR 4334 (S15W59) seen best in SDO AIA 171 starting around 2026-01-04T00:45Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Leading edge measurement using SOHO and STEREO A for triangulation of the longitude.

cmes.note: Outflow-like CME seen to the west in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2A likely associated with far-sided eruptive activity suggested by the geometry of the CME as observed from STEREO A. May be associated with some rising field lines observed behind the northwest limb as seen in SDO AIA 171 around 2026-01-04T04:00Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Low confidence measurement as the front of the CME is not easily seen in available coronagraph imagery.

cmes.note: Faint outflow-like CME seen to the east in SOHO LASCO and not in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap; a possible source for this coronal mass ejection is eruptive activity just behind the eastern limb with a rising prominence seen best in SDO AIA 171 around 2026-01-04T10:24Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: One spacecraft plane of sky measurement as the CME is not seen well in STEREO A COR2A imagery.

cmes.note: Narrow CME seen to the east in SOHO LASCO C2, GOES CCOR-1, and later in STEREO A COR2A which could be associated with a sympathetic eruption near the eastern limb caused by the prominence behind the eastern limb beginning near 2026-01-04T12:00Z seen best in SDO AIA 171.

cmeAnalyses.note: Triangulation of the CME leading edge to determine longitude.

cmes.note: Very faint CME first seen to the SE by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2026-01-04T21:12Z. This CME fades before exiting the field of view in C2 and is therefore not seen in any other coronagraphs. The source of this event is likely some minor field line movement seen along the SE limb in SDO AIA 171.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement using a longitude of E90 due to lack of visible coronagraph imagery and source near the limb.

cmes.note: Narrow, bright CME seen to the south-southeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1 and to the southeast in STEREO A COR2A. The likely source is a thin streamer of plasma lifting from near AR 4334 (S17E43) with noticeable southern deflection seen best in SDO AIA 304 and SDO AIA 171 around 2026-01-05T07:00Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Leading edge measurement using all available spacecraft out to 12 solar radii which suggests strong southern deflection.

cmes.note: Faint CME seen to the southeast in SOHO LASCO, STEREO A COR2A and GOES CCOR-1 possibly associated with a two-part eruption in AR 4334 (S17E43) seen best in SDO AIA 171 around 2026-01-05T08:20Z; while most of the plasma material is directed southward, a portion of the plasma lags behind and is directed to the southeast. May instead be associated with a destabilizing magnetic loop with bright post eruptive arcades high above the AR 4334 (S17E43), but the ejecta does not leave the GOES and SDO EUV field of views until after 09:00Z, suggesting that any such CME associated with the later eruption in AR 4334 is seen after 09:00Z in coronagraph imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Leading edge measurement using SOHO LASCO C2/C3, STEREO A SECCHI COR2A, and GOES CCOR-1 out to about 12 solar radii.

cmes.note: CME seen to the southeast in GOES CCOR-1 and STEREO A COR2 but not in SOHO LASCO due to a data gap; the CME is probably associated with destabilizing magnetic loop with bright post eruptive arcades near AR 4334 (S17E43) seen best in SDO AIA 171 around 2026-01-05T08:20Z seen through 2026-01-05T09:30Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Low confidence leading edge measurement using triangulation between GOES and STEREO A to determine the originating source longitude.
